context: The effects of local surface low pressure are extremely limited because <b10_0>upper-level subsidence<b10_0/> still continues to block <b3_0>any form of <a0_0>air ascent<b3_0/><a0_0/>. Also, to be protected against rain-bearing weather systems by the atmospheric circulation itself, the desert is made even drier by his <b4_0>geographical configuration and location<b4_0/>. Indeed, <b5_0>the extreme aridity of <b11_0>the Sahara<b11_0/><b5_0/> can't be only explained by the <b7_0>subtropical high pressure<b7_0/>. <b6_0><b9_0>The <a1_0>Atlas Mountains<b9_0/><b6_0/><a1_0/>, found in <a2_0><b8_0>Algeria<a2_0/>, Morocco and Tunisia<b8_0/> also help to enhance the aridity of the northern part of the desert. These major mountain ranges act as a barrier causing a strong rain shadow effect on the leeward side by dropping much of the humidity brought by atmospheric disturbances along the polar front which affects the surrounding Mediterranean climates.
